race.name: TORINO NICE RALLY
race.tagline: 700km crossing the Alps from Italy to France on legendary military roads. Where bikepacking pilgrimage meets high-altitude adventure.

vitals.registration: Postcard lottery, ~25 EUR entry fee (includes finisher's party)
vitals.aid_stations: None - fully self-supported. Resupply at villages, refugios, and public establishments.

climate.primary: High Alpine September - extreme temperature swings from valley heat to alpine cold
climate.description: Early September in the Alps presents dramatic conditions. Valley floors can hit 30°C+ heat waves while passes above 2,500m drop below 10°C with potential snow. Col Agnel descents are particularly cold and bleak. Afternoon thunderstorms build ominously in the mountains. Riders must prepare for 20-30°C temperature swings within a single day.
challenges: Snow possible on highest cols even in September
Dust on dry gravel with motor traffic

terrain.primary: Mixed Alpine terrain - paved cols, military gravel roads, rocky doubletrack
terrain.surface: ~65% paved alpine roads, ~35% gravel/military roads. Rocky sections on Strada dei Cannoni require MTB-level skills. Some optional hike-a-bike sections.
features: Gardetta Pass 'Little Peru' - 35km of high mountain gravel
Via del Sale - 30km of dream gravel finale

logistics.explanation: Josh Ibbett warns "Don't underestimate the Colle Del Colombardo, its tough and slow going, but the good news is that most climbs feel easier from here on in." Self-supported cross-border journey from Turin to Nice requires international travel planning. Italian villages provide reliable water tap network, though Josh discovered "Tailfin frame bags are waterproof as long as the zip is shut… if its left open they are also excellent at collecting water."

length.explanation: JKB's team "gave themselves 8 days to ride the TNR, which meant averaging around 85km and a little over 2,000m climbing every day." At 700km across the Maritime Alps, this firmly enters ultra-endurance territory. Josh Ibbett planned his 435-mile journey around "6-7 hours pedalling a day," understanding the multi-day expedition demands differ vastly from single-day gravel events.

technicality.explanation: On Colle del Colombardo, Josh Ibbett describes "wall like lower slopes" where "the gradient lowered the surface deteriorated to a rough rocky dirt track making for slow going and much sweating." Claire Frecknall notes the advantage of wider tires: "After letting some air out and was able to fly past people cautiously picking their way around rocks on skinnier tyres." The Strada Dell Assiette forces riders into "rougher rocks at the edge of the track" when motorbikes pass.

elevation.explanation: The relentless climbing dominates daily rhythm. JKB observes "Those long climbs can take hours over an entire chunk of the day, which puts you in quite a different head space." At 52,493 feet total gain, riders face "a little over 2,000m climbing every day" across ten major cols including Colle delle Finestre at 2,178m and the route's high point at Col Agnel. Among the hilliest in gravel, comparable to Badlands.

climate.explanation: Josh Ibbett reports "Italy was experiencing a late summer heat wave with temperatures well above 30 degrees centigrade" during his 2024 ride. Valley heat creates serious dehydration risk at altitude, while high passes bring sudden weather changes. Josh encountered afternoon storms: "The temperatures in the Valley were high, but in the mountains above me I could see the clouds building ominously."

altitude.explanation: Col Agnel tops out at 2,750m (9,022ft). Extended riding above 2,000m on Strada dell'Assietta and Gardetta Pass. The sweet spot of 2,000-3,000m where peaks escape trees and rocks reveal geological beauty. Significant altitude effects for riders from sea level - labored breathing combined with dust from motor traffic creates unpleasant combinations. Among the highest-altitude events in gravel, on par with Badlands.

adventure.explanation: Sophie Gateau describes accessing Little Peru as "the most epic moment of our expedition" where her team spent "four hours, we push our bikes for most of it. We are overtaken by hikers armed with trekking poles." The cross-border journey through remote military roads and refugio culture defines European bikepacking adventure. Adam Ferris notes how "the first person I spoke to was here for his second year, and when I asked what the first climb was like he smashed his fist into his palm."

prestige.explanation: Founded in 2015 and holding legendary status among European bikepacking events, TNR attracted 180 riders to its 2024 gathering in Turin's Piazza Giambattista Bodoni. Josh Ibbett notes the Sunday night social dinner creates "a chance to meet fellow riders and fill up on pasta or pizza before the start." Lael Wilcox's organization of the historic 2021 Women's TNR established it as the first women's-only bikepacking event in Europe.

race_quality.explanation: Intentionally minimal organization reflects the "not a race" philosophy. 25 EUR entry includes finisher's party and GPX files via Komoot. No aid stations or tracking infrastructure for most editions. The stripped-back approach prioritizes adventure over production, though TrackLeaders provided tracking for the 2021 Women's event.

experience.explanation: Life-changing. Sunrise above 2,500m. Stunning remote bivvy spots at high altitude. Rolling ridgelines on ancient military roads. The refugio culture - Refuge d'Agnel with its stunning sunset views, Rifugio Massacan's warm welcome at the finish. 'Food for your soul' - the event philosophy. Riders describe the experience as transformative, not just memorable.

community.explanation: Legendary community ethos. 'Not a race - adventure with friends.' Rolling community where participants leapfrog, make friends, and help each other. 100% non-profit supporting Smart Shelter Foundation (provides 60% of their annual budget). Women's TNR 2021 created lasting bonds among 26 finishers from 7 countries. The finisher's party tradition embodies the communal spirit.

field_depth.explanation: Attracts dedicated bikepacking enthusiasts rather than competitive racing elite, with field sizes ranging from 30 independent riders to 180 for official editions. JKB's team chose an 8-day leisurely pace while others complete it faster, reflecting the adventure-first philosophy where completion times vary widely. The event draws recreational riders like Josh Ibbett alongside experienced participants, prioritizing route exploration over competitive depth.

value.explanation: 25 EUR entry fee is exceptional value - includes finisher's party with food and beer. Route available for independent riding year-round via Komoot. No lottery system when official event runs. Self-supported nature means you control your own accommodation and food costs. The value proposition is remarkable for a outstanding bikepacking experience.

expenses.explanation: Multi-day international travel requires significant planning and budget for cross-border logistics. Return journey via train costs around 24 EUR for the 5+ hour route from Nice to Turin. Claire Frecknall's setup shows typical equipment investment: "Reilly Gradient on a Mason/Hunt 650b Adventure Dynamo Disc Wheelset and tubeless 47c WTB Venture tyres" plus multi-day food and accommodation costs during the week-long expedition.

biased_opinion.summary: The Torino Nice Rally represents bikepacking at its purest. 700km crossing the Maritime Alps from Italy to France on legendary military roads, fully self-supported, for 25 EUR. It's not a race - it's a pilgrimage. The Gardetta Pass 'Little Peru' section is described as possibly the most mesmerizing gravel ride in the world. Via del Sale's finale is 30km of dream gravel. The refugio culture, the rolling community, the charity mission for Smart Shelter Foundation - this is what the bikepacking ethos looks like when executed with soul. Founded with Tour Divide inspiration, TNR has earned its legendary status.
strengths: One of the original European bikepacking events with legendary status
Gardetta Pass 'Little Peru' - possibly the world's most mesmerizing gravel
25 EUR entry fee for a world-class 700km Alpine crossing
Strong community ethos and charity mission
weaknesses: Event status uncertain for 2025 - insurance issues
Rocky military roads punish pure gravel bikes
biased_opinion.bottom_line: If you want the quintessential European bikepacking pilgrimage, TNR is the answer. This is what the sport looks like when it's about adventure, community, and soul.

black_pill.title: ALPINE REALITY CHECK
black_pill.reality: 700km and 16,000m+ climbing through the high Alps is not a casual endeavor. Weather can turn brutal - snow and unrelenting rain have stopped riders in Sampeyre. Strada dei Cannoni features rocks that punish anything under 47mm tires. Massive rockslides can wipe away roads completely - one rider descended 1,000m to find the road gone, forcing a choice between retracing steps or sketching across scattered rocks. The hike-a-bike sections are genuinely steep - 4 hours pushing bikes while being overtaken by hikers with trekking poles.
consequences: Weather-forced scratches happen regularly on high passes
Rocky military roads can destroy equipment and confidence
Self-supported means no one is coming when things go wrong
Exhausted brains work less efficiently after 4-5 days in the mountains
black_pill.expectation_reset: This requires very good fitness and advanced riding skills. Some portions may require pushing your bike. The climbs will take you out of your touring comfort zone. Bring gear for both 30°C valleys and potential snow at 2,750m. Have contingency plans for road closures and weather delays. Respect what 700km through the Alps actually demands.

final_verdict.one_liner: The quintessential European bikepacking pilgrimage - 700km crossing the Alps on legendary military roads for 25 EUR.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Yes if you want authentic bikepacking adventure without commercial racing pressure. Yes if you appreciate community, charity, and soul over competition. Yes if you're prepared for multi-day Alpine self-sufficiency. Skip if you need race infrastructure and support. Skip if rocky military roads will destroy your pure gravel setup.
final_verdict.alternatives: Badlands (similar European ultra, more extreme heat); Transcontinental Race (longer European ultra); The Traka 360 (Spanish bikepacking with more infrastructure)

logistics.airport: TRN (Turin) - start; NCE (Nice) - finish. Both cities have rail connections from major European hubs.
logistics.lodging_strategy: Turin for pre-event. During ride: mountain refuges (Refuge d'Agnel, Rifugio Gardetta, Rifugio Casa Assietta), small hotels, wild camping at altitude. Rifugio Massacan at Nice finish provides logistics help, shower, and warm welcome.
logistics.food: Self-supported - resupply at Italian villages with good water tap networks. Via del Sale has very rare fountains - plan ahead. Refuges provide meals and packed lunches for next day.
logistics.packet_pickup: Group start from Piazza Giambattista Bodoni, Turin (when official event runs).
logistics.camping:
Camping
- Key: Be discreet, arrive late, leave early
- Don't hop fences into private land
- Technically not permitted but accept

history.origin_story: James Olsen created the route in 2015 for a bike testing trip. The first rally event ran in 2016, inspired by the Tour Divide's free, unregulated ethos promoting good ethics. Olsen met Martijn Schildkamp (Smart Shelter Foundation founder) in Nepal in 2008 while building a wind-break bivvy spot at Annapurna base camp - this connection led to TNR's charity partnership.
notable_moments: 2021: Historic Women's TNR led by Lael Wilcox - first women's-only bikepacking event in Europe
2018-2024: Provided ~60% of Smart Shelter Foundation's annual budget through patches and sponsorships
2024: No official event - riders rode independently while organizers addressed insurance
history.reputation: One of the original European bikepacking events. Legendary status in the community. Where Tour Divide ethos meets Alpine adventure.

course_description.character: A 700km pilgrimage across the Maritime Alps from Turin's Piazza Giambattista Bodoni to Nice's Rifugio Massacan. The route weaves between Italy and France across 10+ major cols, alternating between legendary Tour de France climbs and historic military gravel roads. 65% paved alpine roads, 35% gravel including the sublime Gardetta Pass 'Little Peru' and Via del Sale finale. Every day takes riders over passes above 2,000m. The sweet spot between 2,000-3,000m where peaks escape trees and sky becomes more blue.

suffering_zones.label: Colle del Colombardo
suffering_zones.desc: First major challenge after leaving Turin. 'Potentially the toughest of them all.' 18%+ gradients on tarmac degrading to rough gravel doubletrack at 14%+.

suffering_zones.label: Colle delle Finestre
suffering_zones.desc: Famous Giro d'Italia climb. 19km, 1,700m vertical. Last 8km on fine gravel. Site of Chris Froome's 2018 race-winning attack.

suffering_zones.label: Col Agnel
suffering_zones.desc: Highest point at 2,750m. 20+ km climb at 6.6% average. Descent 'particularly cold and bleak, especially for toes.'

suffering_zones.label: Gardetta Pass 'Little Peru'
suffering_zones.desc: 35km of high mountain gravel wilderness. 'Possibly the most mesmerizing gravel ride in the world.' The sweet spot of the entire event.

suffering_zones.label: Col de Turini
suffering_zones.desc: 26km unrelenting climb with 1,700m vertical. The final major Alpine test.

suffering_zones.label: Via del Sale
suffering_zones.desc: 30km unpaved finale. 'Complete joy, dream gravel, amazing views.' Last point feeling completely enveloped by Alps. Far from inhabited centers - very rare fountains.

course_description.signature_challenge: The complete Alpine crossing - 700km, 16,000m+ climbing, legendary military roads, self-supported through the Maritime Alps from Italy to France.

citations.label: cafeducycliste.com: Tracing The Torino Nice Rally
bikepacking.com: Take Me Back To The Mountains
huntbikewheels.cc: Riding The Turin Nice Rally

primary.name: Pirelli Cinturato Gravel S
primary.why: high puncture protection for sharp surfaces. excellent wet grip

primary.name: Schwalbe G-One Overland
primary.why: high puncture protection for sharp surfaces. excellent wet grip

youtube_data.search_query: TORINO NICE RALLY gravel race Turin

videos.title: INSIDE THE "TORINO-NICE RALLY" (2016)
videos.description:
The “Torino – Nice Rally” is not a race, it is rather food for your soul: an adventure with friends and a memorable experience. 700km on old military cols and scenic historical trade routes leading all the way from the western Italian Alpes down to the coast of southern France. 

In 2016 our ambassador JOACHIM ROSENLUND took part in the rally (on his HOOK EXT) and experienced some truly incredible unsupported bikepacking. The backdrop of Europe's highest mountains never cease to take our breath away, but we couldn’t prepare ourselves for quite how spectacular his journey would be.

As an event in-between all Joachim’s annual long-distance competitions the "Torino-Nice Rally" seemed to be the perfect 'recovery’ ride, without pressure, and ‘only' 20,000m of elevation. The rally made such an impression on him that he’s already signed up for the 2017 edition again….to see what exactly brought him back for a repeat visit check out the video, and if you’re tempted to ride it yourself be sure to say ”Hi” to him in Turin. 

Rider: Joachim Rosenlund (bombtrack.com/team/joachim/) 
 Production: Tina Lagler & Blaž Miklič / OSM Films (osmfilms.com)
 Sounddesign: Guido Craveiro at Pork & Rabbit Studios, Pulheim 
 Graphic Design: Marko Šajn / cognitive-state.com
 Music: Homeless Atlantic “Newfoundland” & “Drift”, Dana Boulé “Clichy Waltz”

More information about the event: torino-nice.weebly.com/ 
More information about the bike: bombtrack.com/bikes/hook-ext/ 

Homeless Atlantic’s “Newfoundland” and “Drift” appears courtesy of copyright control and is taken from the longplayer “The North Passage”

instagram.com/bombtrackbicycleco/ 
bombtrackbicycleco.tumblr.com/
twitter.com/Bombtrack17 
facebook.com/344264558942333

Homeless Atlantic are Matt Gutteridge and Sean Crookes. For more great music and information visit homelessatlantic1.bandcamp.com/ and facebook.com/homelessatlantic

Bombtrack Bicycle Co. is a division of WE MAKE THINGS GmbH, Cologne / Germany.

videos.curation_reason: High-view experiential first-person account with specific details about course conditions and the mental challenges of the rally.

videos.title: Torino - Nice Rally  -  Bikepacking over Mountain Passes with Breathtaking Views
videos.description:
This is possibly the biggest thing we have ever done in bikepacking!  It has taken a while to edit in the background so apologies for the delay. In 2023 we headed out to Torino Italy with the aim of riding the whole of the 800+ km of the Torino Nice Rally from the "Unofficial" Group start.  

We were completely blown away, not just by the entire day long climbs, but the absolutely stunning views and  simply spectacular scenery.  Riding along observing the way of life in these Alpine areas was such a break from the modern day of UK Life.  

We used our tent all of the nights, wild camping  and staying in the grounds of the Mountain Refuges.  The whole experience was overwhelming and had a huge impact on our desire to explore more of the world by bike. 

If. you would like more information on the route please don't hesitate to check out their webiste. 
https://torino-nice.weebly.com/intro.html

videos.curation_reason: Recent detailed first-person ride-along with excellent production quality and specific course insights from participants completing the full route.

videos.title: Pt1 A Hard Start | Torino Nice Rally | Part 1
videos.description:
The Torino Nice Rally starts hard.  This video sets out the route then climbs the Colombardo and Finestre passes before leading onto the first section of high gravel, the Strada Assietta to Casa Assietta.

 Adventure Crew channel members can watch a 30 minute video of the whole ride now - Join here: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCuSEN52fnqKmD99JkfexTGA/join

My route: https://www.komoot.com/collection/1801324/-my-torino-nice-rally-route
Official 2022 route: https://www.komoot.com/collection/1676712/-tnr-2022-official-route
TNR website: https://torino-nice.weebly.com/

Pt1 (1 Oct): https://youtu.be/VwN0Xs-PjLA
Pt2 (2 Oct): https://youtu.be/i9GjiQUM0mY
Pt3 (5 Oct): https://youtu.be/upKa5rCjfns
Pt4 (9 Oct): https://youtu.be/8WpYe_UXX88
Key Info (16 Oct): https://youtu.be/myyacQeg3W4

Written articles
Include about, travelling to and from, plus kit - what works
 https://simon-willis.blogspot.com/2022/09/torino-nice-rally-1-what-you-need-to.html

Items I was loaned or given for the TNR - Amazon affiliate links
Terra Nova Laser 1 Compact Tent: https://www.terra-nova.co.uk/products/laser-compact-1/
Rab Neutrino 200 Sleeping bag: https://rab.equipment/uk/neutrino-200
Giro Rumble Shoes: https://amzn.to/3dv5tyy
Redshift Kitchen-sink Handlebars: https://amzn.to/3Ut5UKl
Redshift Shock-stop stem: https://amzn.to/3R2YrPs
Kitchen Sink bag: https://amzn.to/3R0oLtA
Darn Tough Socks: https://amzn.to/3QZPshR
Tubolito Inner tubes: https://amzn.to/3fovYpZ
Quad Lock: https://www.quadlockcase.co.uk/collections/shop-cycle

Rough Stuff Cycling in the Alps by Isola Press: https://www.isolapress.com/shop/roughstuff-alps

SUPPORT
Join the Crew: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCuSEN52fnqKmD99JkfexTGA/join
Buy me a Kofi: https://ko-fi.com/sunartmedia

FOLLOW
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/always_another_adventure/
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/AlwaysAnotherAdventure
Maps & rides on Komoot: https://www.komoot.com/user/alwaysanotheradventure
Strava: https://www.strava.com/athletes/1231296

MY VIDEO KIT https://tinyurl.com/myvideokit 

MY CYCLING & CAMPING KIT https://tinyurl.com/mycyclingkit

videos.curation_reason: High-quality recent race recap with specific route details and tactical insights from the challenging opening climbs.

videos.title: Turin to Nice gravel bikepacking 2025
videos.description:
Four friends on a 7-day bikepacking trip from Turin to Nice, roughly following the route of the Turin to Nice Rally through the western Italian and French Alps over tarmacked roads and off-road gravel tracks.
Komoot route: https://www.komoot.com/collection/3562284/-tnr-2025?ref=collection
#bikepacking #turinnicegravel #turinnicerally #cyclingadventure #biketouring #gravelcycling #turinnice #turintonicegravelrally #turinnicebikepacking
videos.transcript:
Here
they are altogether at the start
above average in age, some above average
in waistline, and vastly below average
in knowing their limits. Setting off
from Turin, they were aiming to reach
Nice in 7 days.
This first day was to be quite typical
of what was to come.
Would they make it to Nice? I wouldn't
bet on it.
The usual traffic getting out of a big
city like Churin negotiated safely
through pretty villages and countryside.
It was all smiles as they progressed
along flat roads.
And then this
Cole de Colombardo, a brute of a climb.
The smiles were gone as they wondered
about their life choices.
And here they are living the dream, the
uphill dream. Maybe this wasn't such a
good idea after all.
After nearly 3 hours of climbing, they
reached the top.
Then reward sweeping gravel descents,
thin mountain air, and views that make
all the wheezing worthwhile. smiling
politely while vibrating violently with
a few wobbles.
Back to the Souza Valley at the end of a
tough first day,
finishing late into the evening.
After a comfortable night in the village
of Myana Duza at the foot of the famous
Golo de Finestre Climb, the guys faced
another tough day of climbing.
Much of it on gravel.
This climb followed the route of stage
20 of the 2025 Jiro Ditalia.
The first 9 km of the climb are on
tarmac and then 8 km on gravel to the
top of the pass.
That's
another climb of almost 3 hours
completed. 33 hairpin bends or dornanti
in Italian.
Happy faces again having completed the
first climb of the day. A short coffee
stop in a mountain refuge and then they
were back on the road
and on to the next challenge of the day.
The Strada de lasetta.
The Strada is one of the most
spectacular roads on the route.
The gravel was rough as they rattled
along, wondering if their fillings would
survive.
Marveling at the views,
their bikes weighed between 17 and 20
kg, luggage included.
The Strada de lasetta hovers between

videos.title: Torino Nice Rally 2022
videos.description:
12th to 17th September 2022, we rode from Turin to Nice via the Torino-Nice Rally route. 

Day 1 - Turin to Rifugio Vulpot
Day 2 - Rifugio Vulpot to Cesena Torinese via Colle Colombardo, Colle delle Finestre + Strada dell'Assietta. It's brutal when you find you find your booked rifugio is closed as the sun goes down.
Day 3 - Cesena Torinese to Refuge Agnel via Col d'Izoard + Col Agnel with a monsoon over the Izoard
Day 4 - Refuge Agnel to Rifugio della Gardetta via Col Agnel (again), Colle Sampeyre, Italy's death road and a subsequent police fine, + hike-a-bike up Passo Gardetta
Day 5 - Rifugio della Gardetta to Rifugio Don Barbera via Little Peru, Monumento al Pirata, Col du Tende + Via del Sal.
Day 6 - Rifugio Don Barbera to Café du Cycliste, Nice via the end of Via del Sal and a 30km hot and rocky climb up to La Redoute and the Col de Turini.

quotes.text: So, we're only about 500 meters from the top of the Caldell Colombardo. It has been a huge climb. Biggest climb we've ever done. And we've been walking quite a large amount of it is just such a long climb. You're so tired.
The rally itself it's 700 km with about 18,000 M of climbing 50% of that on gravel and in parts really it's not more gravel anymore it's like big rocks and things so it's technical.
After the dead straight approach to the mountains the colombardo is a brute broken tarmac becomes loose gravel to the 1800 meter cull then the TNR goes higher still. It's like riding up a wall.
